EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

PER 40CFR 68.155(a)



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM



1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response

The PSE Ferndale Generating Station in Ferndale, Washington handles anhydrous ammonia which is considered hazardous by EPA.  The toxicity of ammonia at high concentrations make it necessary to observe certain safety precautions to prevent unnecessary human exposure, and to reduce the threat to the personal health of our employees as well as nearby members of the community.  It is our policy to adhere to all applicable Federal and State rules and regulations.  Safety depends upon the manner in which we handle ammonia, the safety devices inherent in the design of the facility, combined with the safe handling procedure that we use and the training of our personnel.



PSE Ferndale Generating Station's emergency response program is designed to effectively respond to an accidental release of ammonia.  The emergency response plan includes procedure for notification of the Emergency Planning Commission (LEPC), the Washington State Emergency Management Division, and the National Response Center.



2. The Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

The primary purpose of the PSE Ferndale Generating Station is to provide electric power from combustion of natural gas.  Diesel may be used as an alternative fuel.  Anhydrous ammonia is used at the facility to reduce the formation of oxides of nitrogen (NOx) produced during combustion.  Access to the site is restricted to authorized facility employees, authorized management personnel and authorized contractors.



3. Offsite Consequences Analysis

An offsite consequence analysis was conducted for the worst-case and alternative-case release scenarios.  The findings from this analysis were submitted to the EPA in this RMP plan.



4. Accidental Release Prevention Program

The PSE Ferndale Generating Station complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable state cod

es and regulations.  This facility was designed and constructed in accordance with all applicable ammonia storage and handling codes.  All employees involved with the operation or maintenance of the anhydrous ammonia system are thoroughly trained using Ferndale's Facility documented training program.



5. Five-Year Accident History

No accidental releases of ammonia causing on-site injury or damage have occurred during the life of this facility.



6. Emergency Response Program

PSE Ferndale Generating Station's emergency response program is based upon an accidental release of ammonia.  We have discussed this program with the Whatcom County Emergency Planning Committee and the Ferndale Fire Department.
